meanings.definition: The state of being no longer needed or useful.
meanings.sent1: The redundancy of the old machine led to its replacement.
meanings.sent2: The company had to lay off employees due to financial redundancy.
meanings.sent3: It was comical how the broken clock displayed redundancy by chiming at random times.
meanings.sent4: The redundancy of the outdated software was like carrying an extra suitcase on a short trip.
meanings.sent5: The redundancy of the backup generator saved the day during the power outage.

meanings.definition: The inclusion of extra components that are not necessary.
meanings.sent1: The redundancy of the safety features made the car heavier.
meanings.sent2: The redundancy in the system caused delays in processing orders.
meanings.sent3: The cake decorator added redundancy by putting extra icing on the already sweet dessert.
meanings.sent4: The redundancy of the spare key in the drawer felt like a safety net.
meanings.sent5: The redundancy of the backup plan ensured the event would run smoothly.

meanings.definition: The use of more words than are needed to convey meaning.
meanings.sent1: His speech was full of redundancy, repeating the same points over and over.
meanings.sent2: The redundancy in her writing made the essay longer but less clear.
meanings.sent3: The teacher's redundancy in explaining the concept made the students giggle.
meanings.sent4: The redundancy in the contract made it difficult to understand the terms clearly.
meanings.sent5: The redundancy in the presentation made it hard to stay focused on the main idea.
